item.description: What is it? A place for GBIF staff to report interesting analytical results. Stats Tutorials Ideas Opinions Who can contribute? No posts on this blog are to be considered a GBIF or Institutional policy. What about the developer blog? An archive of the developer blog is still available at http://gbif.

item.title: Plot almost anything using the GBIF maps api
item.description: The GBIF maps api is an under-used but powerful web service provided by GBIF. The maps api is used by the main GBIF portal to create the maps including the big map used on gbif.org. item.title: Finding Gridded Datasets
item.description: EBCC Atlas of European Breeding Birds (gridded) Naturalis Biodiversity Center (NL) - Aves (not gridded) Gridded data in GBIF Gridded datasets are a known problem at GBIF. Many datasets have an equally-spaced points in a regular pattern. These datasets are usually systematic national surveys or data taken from some atlas (“so-called rasterized collection designs”). In this blog post I will describe how I found each gridded dataset in GBIF.

item.title: GBIF Download Trends
item.description: Explanation of tool This tool plots the downloads through time for species or other taxonomic groups with more than 25 downloads at GBIF. Downloads at GBIF most often occur through the web interface. In a previous post, we saw that most users are downloading data from GBIF via filtering by scientific name (aka Taxon Key). Since the GBIF index currently sits at over 1 billion records (a 400+GB csv), most users will simplying filter by their taxonomic group of interest and then generate a download.
